citations.narrative:
Two separate bird enclosures contained items that could be injurious to the animals within:
- Mounted on the side fence, near the waterer in the macaw catch pen, were the remnants of a wooden pole fragmented
into two big chunks with the middle 2 feet missing. Three separate pieces of wood remained, about 1.5 to 2 feet long, with
irregular/jagged/chewed edges all throughout. One damaged piece formed into pointed ends on both sides. 4 exposed
nails were seen on the wooden pieces. Exposed sharp points such as these within an enclosure could result in animal
injury.
- There were a few indentations and gaps in the dirt floor along the edges of the cockatoo enclosure at the top of the hill.
The deepest gap, located below the fence shared by the front catch pen and the hallway between the two entrances, was
approximately 3 inches deep and 6 inches long. Such gaps could result in animal injury, could enable an escape and
could potentially allow entry of dangerous/unwanted animals.
Sharp points and gaps below fencing within enclosures may negatively impact the welfare of the birds within. Housing
facilities must be kept in good repair to protect the birds from injury. Correct by 03/21/2025

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility’s enrichment plan specifies that “all bird aviary is equipped with nesting/hide boxes…” At the time of
inspection, the macaw and cockatoo enclosures, both located on top of the hill, did not have nesting or hide boxes. The
written document was thus not updated to reflect the current plan in use.
Per a facility representative, nest boxes were repeatedly provided to the macaws over the past year with each time
triggering severely aggressive behaviors in the birds. During brief moments without boxes (old ones destroyed and new
ones not yet placed), the abnormal behaviors would improve. Although the facility acknowledged the aggression was
intrinsically tied to the presence of the boxes, they continued to provide these enrichment items that did not promote the
animals’ psychological well-being.
The facility must develop, document and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to
promote the psychological well-being of the birds. Correct by 03/21/2025.

On February 18, 2025, a blue and gold macaw was found dead in his enclosure with puncture wounds along his back and
wings. According to the facility's disposition records, the bird was likely killed during a “fight” since severely aggressive
behaviors were seen in this aviary over the past year in association with the addition of nest boxes. The facility explained
that changing the amount or the location of enrichment items over the year did not allow for the return to peaceful
cohabitation yet the colony was maintained as is. This incompatibility persisted since the nest boxes continued to be
introduced and culminated in the death of this blue and gold macaw. Birds may not be housed with other animals,
including members of their own species, unless they are compatible, do not prevent access to food, water, or shelter by
individual animals, and are not known to be hazardous to the health and well-being of each other. Corrected at the time of
inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Patricia Laracuente, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
